awd_titl_txt: Pathway Control in Dynamic Covalent (DC) Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Molecular cages are emerging as a unique class of compounds with potential applications in catalysis, battery technology, and filtrations and separations. These single molecules have three-dimensional shapes, variable sizes, and empty space in their interiors. The most efficient way to build molecular cages and other shape-persistent architectures is the synthetic process known as dynamic covalent chemistry (DCC). Using DCC means that chemists can build structures with simple precursors which "self-assemble" into the desired geometry over the course of a single chemical reaction rather than building structures step-by-step over many reactions. However, a major challenge when using DCC is the difficulty in predicting what precursor is best to obtain the desired architecture. Currently, the Moore group of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champain is working toward a set of guidelines for DCC which will help chemists design better precursors and synthetic strategies for building three-dimensional architectures.  This project supports the education and professional development for future researchers and educators, preparing for a workforce for the science and engineering fields.  In addition, the Moore Group members participate in public outreach and educational activities (e.g., Encouraging Tomorrow's Chemists events for local middle schools) to communicate and promote a strong literacy in science for the next generation. 

With the support from the NSF Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program, the Moore group is using alkyne metathesis as a model DCC reaction to study the relationship between exchange rate and product distribution, especially in cases where kinetic traps are known to form. DCC describes reversible reactions where molecular components can exchange freely until a thermodynamic minimum is achieved, and kinetic traps arise when exchange rates are too slow and/or the building blocks have a high valance. The team aims to build a computational model that describes the relationship between exchange rates, valancy, and product distribution. The computational model is designed to provide chemists with a better understanding of which DCC reactions or reaction conditions are necessary to access predicted structures. Additionally, the model predicts when kinetic traps are likely to arise in a given reaction and the maximum product yield that can be expected. The computational model is supplemented with experimentally obtained kinetic data for both simple and complex alkyne metathesis reactions. Once the fundamentals are established, they will be used as a guide for accessing more complex shape-persistent molecular architectures of nanoscale dimension.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how to create well-defined nanoscale architectures is of great importance to the development of new technologies for water purification, gas storage and separation, drug delivery, impact-dissipating materials, and lithium-ion batteries. One approach to generating these structures uses dynamic covalent chemistry (DCC), which typically enables intuitive synthetic planning and gives high yields of well-defined nanostructures. However, these heuristic approaches fail when applied to increasingly complex 2- and 3-dimensional architectures, as they ignore factors contributing to the formation of undesired, kinetically trapped side products. These strategies also limit the kinds of chemical functionalities that the products can possess. To address these issues, we sought to establish theoretical and experimental methods to probe reaction pathways for DCC self-assembly, then use that information to develop strategies to avoid kinetic traps and generate molecular architectures with precise spatial geometries and multiple chemical functionalities.

 

One of the major limitations in dynamic covalent (DC) synthesis is the lack of a theoretical framework to predict reaction outcomes. To address this problem, we generated a rule-based model (RBM)  to predict the outcome of the DC assembly of a molecular ladder. This computational tool allows us to rationalize why a DCC self-assembly reaction might not succeed and provides guidance for developing strategies to ensure success. We found that as the rate of the DC exchange reaction increases, the likelihood of forming kinetically trapped side products decreases. In a complementary study, we found that alkyne metathesis catalysts are deactivated during the course of a typical DC assembly reaction, slowing the rate of exchange. Taken together, these results indicate that the rate of addition of catalyst to a DCC reaction, as well as temperature, total catalyst loading, and reaction concentration can all have a significant impact on the outcome of self-assembly reactions. Though our RBM was designed for one specific DCC system, extension of this approach, combined with experimental determination of kinetic parameters, will enable the rational design of complex structures, such as 2D materials and 3D frameworks.

 

Although products formed by kinetic (rather than thermodynamic) control are often considered undesirable in DCC, understanding reaction pathways that lead to their formation may allow access to otherwise synthetically inaccessible structures. In the DCC synthesis of a Möbius macrocycle, our group found that only two of several possible products were formed, despite the fact that these species were not the lowest-energy outcomes typically expected for a DCC self-assembly reaction. Further investigation revealed that this selectivity arose from the geometric strain of key transition states during macrocycle formation, which rendered the lowest-energy products inaccessible. This surprising result illustrates the value of understanding reaction pathways to rationalize unexpected DCC outcomes and provides insight into the ways in which kinetic selectivity could be leveraged for future DCC synthesis.

 

The incorporation of multiple chemical functionalities into nanoscale architectures is a major goal for the development of chemically responsive structures for applications in drug delivery and self-healing materials. However, the lack of methods to rationally design such architectures, as well as the limited number of compatible DC reactions, make exploration of orthogonal dynamic covalent chemistries (ODCCs) for material synthesis challenging. To address this problem, we studied the orthogonality of alkyne metathesis and imine exchange. We found that these chemistries can operate in tandem by judicious choice of reaction conditions including catalyst selection, order of addition of reaction components, and removal of water. We also used these chemistries to construct a molecular cage containing imine and alkyne functionalities that could be selectively disassembled and reassembled in the presence of a Lewis acid catalyst. The discoveries in these studies serve as user guidelines for future applications of orthogonal alkyne metathesis and imine exchange and demonstrate the utility of ODCC in generating molecular architectures with precise control over structure and functionality.

 

Our work has yielded theoretical and chemical tools to identify and circumvent sources of failure in DCC self-assembly reactions, as well as strategies to generate molecular architectures with precisely controlled symmetry and functionality. The results of these studies will be instrumental in the rational design and synthesis of materials for next-generation technologies with a wide range of applications beyond fundamental research.


Last Modified: 12/19/2022
Modified by: Jeffrey S Moore
